I know everyone wants to use it for sexo, but this openai chatbot is actually really helpful for figuring out Linux commands if you're a scriptlet or forget shit constantly like me. It's easier than combing through stackoverflow, anyways.

>Can you give me a linux equivalent for the Windows command "powercfg /a"?
The Linux equivalent for the Windows command "powercfg /a" is "cat /sys/power/state". This command shows the current power state of the system. You can use the command "cat /sys/power/mem_sleep" to see the available sleep states for the system.


>Give me a ffmpeg command that resizes a video's resolution to 1080p while copying the audio stream and encodes it to HEVC with nvenc at lossless quality.
>Then write a bash script that executes this command for every .mp4 and .mkv file in the current directory and writes it to a new file with "-1080p" appended to the filename.

#!/bin/bash

# Create an array containing the names of all .mp4 and .mkv files in the current directory
files=(*.mp4 *.mkv)

# Loop through each file in the array
for file in "${files[@]}"
do
  # Generate the output filename by appending "-1080p" to the original filename
  output="${file%.*}-1080p.${file##*.}"

  # Execute the ffmpeg command, using the current file as the input and the output file name generated above
  ffmpeg -i "$file" -vf scale=1920:1080 -c:v hevc_nvenc -qp 0 -preset lossless -c:a copy "$output"
done

function chessBoard(w, h) {
    if (w <= 0 || h <= 0) {
        return "
".repeat(h + 1);

    const line = "# ".repeat(w >> 1) + (oddWidth ? "#" : "");

${line2}

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90109708
Did a little digging and there seems to be an easy solution.
In the Windows install that's already in the PC open up an admin command prompt and type 
slmgr /upk

This uninstalls the license. Then you can type 
slmgr /cpky
to remove the key from the registry.
Then try installing LTSC again, hopefully this time it won't install in S Mode.

threads.com: Which textbook has changed your life / career?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Inference - Rohatgi
Why I recommend it? The real answer is super long. But the short version is - there are thinkers & there are doers. Basically, the mathematical statistics world has these theory-building Bourbaki type guys who write a LOT, say a LOT, but never get to the fucking point (imho). The opposite view is "Math is bunch of tricks. its like chess - more middlegames & endgames you know, higher chance of winning. No real point in learning who originally came up with this particular middle game variation, or why does this opening work etc etc. Just learn the trick & play the game." So that's the eastern (Indian/Chinese) school of thought, which is what I subscribe to.

The book is essentially grab-bags of tricks. Do this - it works - now try it on these problems - ok next trick...on & on. So I solved the 100+ problems & now I know lots of these methods that just work.

So that's the thing. rohatgi is about real world, down & dirty, how to do stuff. how to solve actual problems.

And it's locked enough that I don't spend all of my free time tinkering it. I already spend 7 hours a day working on UNIX servers, when I get home I really don't need the autistic urge to reconfigure X or Y software.
I still feel conflicted about using closed source software and privacy and feel like I might snap and install debian on this bitch at any given time,. But it's doing wonders for my mental health that my OS is not my main hobby anymore.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90105690
I have a surface pro 7 and if it weren't for the fact I got the absolute base-est model (8/128gb) I wouldn't even think about replacing it.
They're pretty niche but they're nice in their own way.
Having a light, small laptop is very nice when you carry it around in your backpack all day (like in uni) and it's nice to be able to hand-write with it (even if the stylus is separately sold and is expensive).
A year ago I'd tell you using it as a tablet is miserable because Windows just isn't built with that in mind, but after the recent updates it became FAR nicer to use touch-only with increased targets and a UI that behaves like you'd expect a touch screen device to behave.
It's still not comfortable to hold it in both hands on a couch and lazily browse 4chan because it's large and heavy relative to a tablet, but it's intuitive now, which is great.

The SP7 in particular (and the SP line in general) is lovely, great screen, good-enough speakers to be pleasantly usable for videos, surprisingly nice keyboard cover (which is sold separately and is once again expensive, the bastards) and the 7 even has an SD card slot for my media hoarding desires (which they took away going from the 8 onward)
It's passively cooled but it never bothered me when I was away from home and at home I just pointed a tiny fan at it and it sorted it out.

Would I recommend one? eh, only if you REALLY want an x86 laptop and a tablet and don't want them to be separate devices, if you don't care for touch screens you might as well get an M1 air, similarly priced, weighs roughly the same, only slightly larger but with a far better everything, ESPECIALLY battery life which is so-so at best on my machine (and I suspect its successors too) and is tablet-like on the M1.

TL;DR: My SP7 is good, got even better with recent Windows updates, but I'd only recommend it if you REALLY want to do hand writing with your small computer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>90107667
>but after the recent updates it became FAR nicer to use touch-only
Windows 10 or 11?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90108087
11 specifically.
You could see it was designed to be touch friendly from the start but relatively recent updates made it far more practical to navigate the computer just by touch input.
Larger touch targets, tap and holding being analogous to a right click, pinching zooming web pages and pdfs in and out, certain intuitive gestures that do stuff like minimize all windows, windows-key+tab, switch virtual desktops, dragging and holding working better, swiping working intuitively, double tapping on the side of a youtube or netflix video skipping 5/10 seconds like it would on a tablet and more stuff I'm probably forgetting.
It's not as good as an OS that's designed around using primarily touch input and a keyboard and mouse is still the most comfortable way to do the vast majority of things but some things became less of a hassle to do.
For example if I want to zoom in on a pdf and I have a keyboard attached it's more comfortable to just zoom in the same way you would on a phone rather than clicking a + icon or shift+scroll.
Or if I have it next to me with the keyboard detached and I want to type something very quickly (or even use a combination like ctrl+something) it's often easier to just do it through the virtual keyboard than to go find the cover.
If you use WSA you get to use android apps very effortlessly too, but with my 8gb of RAM I immediately go to swap even if I have nothing else open.
(Although I'm pleasantly surprised with how much I can get away with while limited to 8gb of RAM)

I still think getting a surface pro to double as a laptop and a tablet is a compromise compared to getting to separate devices, it's a bit hard to recommend except for niche uses, but my experience using the thing has improved over time.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I have spent the last couple days searching around and testing different text gen apps, here are my findings:

>https://openai.com/
Free trial authenticated via SMS text, heavily filtered/censored. Great for messing around, horrible for smut. Gets pricey fast. Requires google account.

>https://www.gomoonbeam.com/
Free trial of 100k words authenticated via SMS text message. Zero censorship/filters, ultimate smut machine. They will ban you eventually for smut even though its not censored anywhere between instantly and 24 hours later, likely depending on whether they have someone sifting through flagged inputs at the moment or not.

>https://aiprogrammer.hashlab.jp/
Always free, used to be the best smut machine on the net until prompt injections were defeated here. Still functions great as a tool that writes code for you.

>https://beta.character.ai/
Most people know of this one. Free, account required. Nobody gets banned from here, but output is heavily censored. Great for its intended use of custom chatbots.

>https://chibi.ai/
7-9$ entry fee for 5k words, uses very outdated GPT-2 or possibly older neo/J models, useless for coherent output. Worse than most free apps. Advertises it allows toxic inputs on the website but it doesnt really matter because the output is very poor quality.

>https://blog-title-generator.vercel.app/
Fun little blog title generator. Prompt injections don't work.

>https://aidungeon.io
Classic choose your own adventure RPG textgen, heavily censored, account required.

>https://koboldai.net/
The only worthwhile local install textgen, free, still nowhere near the current capabilities of GPt-3 but certainly better than what some paid GPT-2 services offer. Requires capable hardware specs.


Thread is for discussing all textgen tools/apps, links, and prompting tricks.
